In view of our promise to have the present document before the Foundation
by February 1, however, it was felt desirable to submit it in this preliminary draft
by that time, for whatever discussion and further preparation, investigation/, or
explanation may be indicated.
One of the other problems which might be explored in such a preliminary
meeting as is suggested is this: although all of the Deans of Education so far con¬
sulted are sympathetic to such a proposal as tills in general terms, we sometimes
have the uneasy feeling that many other deans and administrators are not aware of
present deficiencies in the communications systems of their own schools, or in
their own concepts* "We also feel that many are not aware of the tremendous dif¬
ference which is possible between traditional classroom instruction (at whatever
level) and the new patterns of organization which the full potential of television
and radio, properly understood and viewed, make possible.
For, humble as we are in the face of this problem, we feel that there is a
mutual process of “education” needed, to which we, as well as they, can make
significant contributions. Beginning, therefore, with a few such liberally-oriented
Deans and other officers, we believe that the prospects of developing a workable
understanding of both the need, and the manner of meeting it, will be greatly improved.
